   Assessment and Plan
   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.  Overnight,
   patient has been tachycardic and hypotensive. Lasix drip stopped, given
   total fluid bolus of 750 ml.
   #.Failure to wean from ventilator: Patient has a history of COPD, per
   notes from outside hospital it appears that he was felt to have severe
   COPD and on home O2 and steroids. Patient has failed to wean from
   ventilator; bronchoscopy done at OSH suggested possible
   tracheobronchomalacia. Patient was seen and evaluated by IP on arrival;
   per their notes, they will plan on flexible bronchoscopy once medically
   stabilized. Also in OSH notes there is some report of ?Aspergillus in
   sputum, ?ABPA, but felt not to be cause of his PNA; however, this would
   also fit with eosinophilia. Patient does appear to have significant
   bronchiectasis on CXR which is also a likely explanation for why he may
   be failing to wean from ventilator.
   -IP following, will plan on flex bronchoscopy; patient is now medically
   clear per cardiology
   -ABG to assess current respiratory status on ventilator
   -IgE levels Aspergillus
   #Elevated troponins: Patient was seen and evaluated by Cardiology; per
   the history they obtained from him, they found no evidence of chest
   pain symptoms, and felt that because he is asymptomatic at this time,
   and it is unlikely that his presentation is a true acute coronary
   syndrome requiring emergent cardiac catheterization. Troponins have
   remained stable. Per history that we were able to obtain with a
   translator he has not had any chest pain. One concern is that he may
   have an element of demand ischemia, especially given that he appears to
   be atrial paced at a rate of 90 bpm.
   -Continue ASA
   -Check lipids with AM labs
   -EP consult as patient appears to be atrial paced at rate of 90bpm
   -Beta blocker to help with rate control down to where he has been
   Atrial paced (currently HR 100s-120s)
   -Cardiology has signed off, feel patient stable for any intervention
   that IP wishes.
   .
   #Right eye injection/macular rash around orbit: Patient does describe
   pain in right eye, pain with movement of right eye, difficulty with
   vision out of right eye. Patient was seen by ID & opthomology at OSH,
   initially on Acyclovir, but optho felt that not consistent with
   herpetic eye involvement, most likely chronic conjunctival chemosis.
   Currently no vesicular rash around eye so nothing to biopsy.
   -Ophtho consult in AM as unclear what plan for management of eye was at
   OSH, and patient appears to be experiencing new/worsening symptoms
   # Facial twitching: Appeared as though this may have been a possible
   seizure, though patient did not have clear post-ictal state. Concern
   also for possible air embolus given that episode happened in the
   context of RIJ pull. Will continue to monitor for further signs of
   seizure. Will also need head CT eventually
   -EEG
   -Monitor for signs of seizures
   #Anasarca: Patient was receiving diuresis at OSH; received up to Lasix
   80mg IV BID, then changed to Bumex, which was then d/c'd for
   hypotension. Patient
s weight on admission (presumably dry weight) was
   62 kg. [**Month (only) 51**] be preload dependent given degree of hypotension experienced
   with Lasix.
   -D/c lasix for now as patient appears to be tolerating this poorly,
   becoming tachycardic and hypotensive.
   -Will try to keep patient mildly net negative each day
   #.Leukocytosis: patient was transfered on multiple antibiotics for
   several infections he experienced during 2 months at OSH. At this time,
   he has been taken off all antibiotics, and has been afebrile. However,
   does have mild leukcocytosis (11.8). Will continue to monitor. Sputum
   culture shows  >25 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field, as well as
   1+ gram neg rods. [**Month (only) 51**] represent colonization with pseudomonas given his
   trach. Will plan to treat if patient becomes febrile. Patient also has
   significant history of diarrhea, so will plan to send C.diff cultures.
   -Monitor fever curve
   -F/u pan culture
   -Stool for C.diff
   -Send galactomannan to assess for possible aspergillosis
   #Eosinophilia: Presented to OSH with eosinophilia; however, it
   subsequently normalized. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to adrenal insufficiency
   (patient was on prednisone for unknown amount of time on arrival to
   OSH, unclear how much this was continued), may be secondary to
   parasitic infection given recent travel to [**Country **]; may be secondary
   to medication.
   -Stool for O&P x3
   -AM cortisol
   -Minimize unecassary medications (d/c
d antibiotics, PPI, diuretics,
   betablocker)
   .
   #.Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased ferritin.
   Patient also receiving frequent blood draws which may be contributing
   to drop in HCT as well. Relatively stable this morning (of note,
   patient had multiple attempts at central line placement yesterday).
   (HCT 32.4 yesterday
 29.2 today).
   -Guiaic stools
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   .
   #Elevated alk phos: Alk phos elevated at 236. [**Month (only) 51**] be a continued
   sequelae of shock liver. Will plan to continue to monitor in a few
   days. If continues to be elevated, may consider getting GGT to
   differentiate if this is secondary to increased bone turnover secondary
   to chronic bedbound state.
   -Continue to monitor
   .
   #Hypokalemia: Replete potassium as needed.
   #Hypernatremia: free water flushes via PEG (150 ml q6 hours)
   #Decreased albumin: Measuring prealbumin. Patient most likely
   chronically malnourished given long hospital course. Tube feeds via PEG
   tube, f/u prealbumin.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].
   -Wound care consult
   -Optimize nutrition
   -Frequent repositioning
   .
   FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management with
   .
   ACCESS: Left subclavian in place from OSH. Plan is to d/c left
   subclavian and send tip for culture, PICC placement (if can be done
   over the weekend) vs. LIJ
   CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   .
   EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be
   primary contact person, lives with mother and aware of wishes.
   .
   DISPOSITION: ICU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:

   Multi Lumen - [**2101-11-10**] 11:41 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including COPD, who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further evaluation and management. The patient has been experiencing tachycardia and hypotension overnight, and the Lasix drip was stopped due to these findings. The patient has also been experiencing facial twitching, which may have been a possible seizure, although the patient did not have a clear post-ictal state.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponins, which were initially concerning for a possible acute coronary syndrome. However, the patient was evaluated by cardiology and found to be asymptomatic, and the troponins have remained stable. The patient also has eosinophilia, which may be secondary to adrenal insufficiency, parasitic infection, or medication.

The patient has a history of anemia, which is likely anemia of chronic disease given his long hospital course. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with hypokalemia and hypernatremia.

The patient has several medical complications, including tracheobronchomalacia, bronchiectasis, and possible Aspergillus infection. The patient's respiratory status is being closely monitored, and he is currently on ventilator support.

The patient's skin and wound care are also a concern, as he has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on left ear helix. The patient is also at risk for DVT and has been prescribed heparin SQ prophylaxis.

Based on the patient's condition, the following potential medical complications may arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is already compromised, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of infections and is currently colonized with pseudomonas, which could lead to sepsis.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's troponins are elevated, and he may be at risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or acute coronary syndrome.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of diarrhea and may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection.
5. Skin and wound complications: The patient's skin and wound care are a concern, and further complications could lead to increased risk of infection and poor wound healing.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's facial twitching may be a sign of a neurological complication, such as a seizure disorder or a neurological infection.

The patient's care plan should focus on addressing these potential complications and ensuring that his respiratory, cardiac, and gastrointestinal status are closely monitored. The patient's skin and wound care should also be optimized, and he should be monitored for signs of sepsis.

   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.  Overnight,
   patient has been tachycardic and hypotensive. Lasix drip stopped, given
   total fluid bolus of 750 ml.
   #.Failure to wean from ventilator: Patient has a history of COPD, per
   notes from outside hospital it appears that he was felt to have severe
   COPD and on home O2 and steroids. Patient has failed to wean from
   ventilator; bronchoscopy done at OSH suggested possible
   tracheobronchomalacia. Patient was seen and evaluated by IP on arrival;
   per their notes, they will plan on flexible bronchoscopy once medically
   stabilized. Also in OSH notes there is some report of ?Aspergillus in
   sputum, ?ABPA, but felt not to be cause of his PNA; however, this would
   also fit with eosinophilia. Patient does appear to have significant
   bronchiectasis on CXR which is also a likely explanation for why he may
   be failing to wean from ventilator.
   -IP following, will plan on flex bronchoscopy; patient is now medically
   clear per cardiology
   -ABG to assess current respiratory status on ventilator
   -IgE levels Aspergillus
   #Elevated troponins: Patient was seen and evaluated by Cardiology; per
   the history they obtained from him, they found no evidence of chest
   pain symptoms, and felt that because he is asymptomatic at this time,
   and it is unlikely that his presentation is a true acute coronary
   syndrome requiring emergent cardiac catheterization. Troponins have
   remained stable. Per history that we were able to obtain with a
   translator he has not had any chest pain. One concern is that he may
   have an element of demand ischemia, especially given that he appears to
   be atrial paced at a rate of 90 bpm.
   -Continue ASA
   -Check lipids with AM labs
   -EP consult as patient appears to be atrial paced at rate of 90bpm
   -Beta blocker to help with rate control down to where he has been
   Atrial paced (currently HR 100s-120s)
   -Cardiology has signed off, feel patient stable for any intervention
   that IP wishes.
   .
   #Right eye injection/macular rash around orbit: Patient does describe
   pain in right eye, pain with movement of right eye, difficulty with
   vision out of right eye. Patient was seen by ID & opthomology at OSH,
   initially on Acyclovir, but optho felt that not consistent with
   herpetic eye involvement, most likely chronic conjunctival chemosis.
   Currently no vesicular rash around eye so nothing to biopsy.

s weight on admission (presumably dry weight) was

d antibiotics, PPI, diuretics,

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of COPD, who was admitted to the ICU from the outside hospital (OSH) for further evaluation and management. He has a complex medical history, including a long hospital course, multiple complications, and multiple medications. He is currently on ventilator support and has been experiencing tachycardia and hypotension overnight. His lab results show elevated troponins, eosinophilia, and leukocytosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Failure to wean from ventilator: The patient's history of COPD and tracheobronchomalacia may contribute to his inability to wean from the ventilator.
2. Elevated troponins: The patient's asymptomatic presentation and stable troponin levels suggest that his elevated troponins may not be indicative of an acute coronary syndrome, but rather demand ischemia or chronic cardiac damage.
3. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may be secondary to adrenal insufficiency, parasitic infection, or medication.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be secondary to colonization with pseudomonas or an underlying infection.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be secondary to chronic disease, iron deficiency, or frequent blood draws.
6. Elevated alkaline phosphatase: The patient's elevated alkaline phosphatase may be a sequelae of shock liver or chronic bedbound state.
7. Hypokalemia: The patient's hypokalemia may be secondary to diuretic use or other medications.
8. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may be secondary to free water flushes via PEG tube.
9. Decreased albumin: The patient's decreased albumin may be secondary to chronic malnutrition or chronic illness.
10. Ulcers: The patient's ulcers may be secondary to chronic pressure or poor wound care.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider further cardiac evaluation.
3. Monitor the patient's eosinophilia and leukocytosis and adjust antibiotic therapy as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and consider iron supplementation or other treatments.
5. Monitor the patient's alkaline phosphatase levels and consider further evaluation if levels remain elevated.
6. Monitor the patient's potassium levels and replete as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's albumin levels and consider nutritional supplements or other treatments.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's ulcers and consider wound care consult and nutritional support.

   tracheobronchomalacia. Patient was seen and evaluated by IP on arrival;
   per their notes, they will plan on flexible bronchoscopy once medically

   remained stable. Per history that we were able to obtain with a

Summary:

The patient is a 80-year-old male with a history of COPD, who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of tracheobronchomalacia and possible Aspergillus infection. He has been on multiple antibiotics for several infections during his 2-month hospitalization at OSH. He was transferred to our hospital for further evaluation and treatment. The patient has been experiencing tachycardia and hypotension, and his troponin levels have been elevated. He has also been experiencing right eye injection and macular rash around the orbit, which has been managed with Acyclovir. He has anasarca, leukocytosis, eosinophilia, anemia, elevated alk phos, hypokalemia, hypernatremia, decreased albumin, and ulcers.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Elevated troponin levels may indicate cardiac damage or demand ischemia, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
	* The patient's atrial pacing at a rate of 90 bpm may be a concern for demand ischemia.
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Failure to wean from ventilator may indicate tracheobronchomalacia or other respiratory issues.
	* Sputum culture shows >25 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field, which may indicate colonization with pseudomonas.
3. Infectious Complications:
	* Elevated leukocytosis may indicate infection, which needs to be monitored and treated if necessary.
	* Eosinophilia may be secondary to adrenal insufficiency, parasitic infection, or medication.
4. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Diarrhea may be secondary to infection or medication, and stool cultures need to be sent for C.diff.
5. Nutritional Complications:
	* Anemia may be secondary to chronic disease, iron deficiency, or frequent blood draws.
	* Decreased albumin may indicate chronic malnutrition, which needs to be addressed with tube feeds and nutrition optimization.
6. Skin and Wound Complications:
	* Ulcers on sacrum/coccyx and left ear helix need to be managed with wound care consult and frequent repositioning.
7. Hematological Complications:
	* Elevated alk phos may indicate liver damage or chronic bedbound state, which needs to be monitored and treated if necessary.

Overall, the patient's complex medical history and current condition require close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and improve his outcome.

   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.  Overnight,
   patient has been tachycardic and hypotensive. Lasix drip stopped, given
   total fluid bolus of 750 ml.
   #.Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean from
   ventilator also with bronciectasis.  Bronch at OSH with
   ?tracheobronchomalacia.  IP plans to preform flexible bronchoscopy once
   medically stabilized. From OSH ?Aspergillus in sputum, ?ABPA, but felt
   not to be cause of his PNA; however, this would also fit with
   eosinophilia. Patient does appear to have significant bronchiectasis on
   CXR which is also a likely explanation for why he may be failing to
   wean from ventilator.
   -IP following, will plan on flex bronchoscopy; patient is now medically
   clear per cardiology
   -ABG to assess current respiratory status on ventilator
   -IgE levels Aspergillus
   #Elevated troponins: Patient was seen and evaluated by Cardiology; per
   the history they obtained from him, they found no evidence of chest
   pain symptoms, and felt that because he is asymptomatic at this time,
   and it is unlikely that his presentation is a true acute coronary
   syndrome requiring emergent cardiac catheterization. Troponins have
   remained stable. Per history that we were able to obtain with a
   translator he has not had any chest pain. One concern is that he may
   have an element of demand ischemia, especially given that he appears to
   be atrial paced at a rate of 90 bpm.
   -Continue ASA
   -Check lipids with AM labs
   -EP consult as patient appears to be atrial paced at rate of 90bpm
   -Beta blocker to help with rate control down to where he has been
   Atrial paced (currently HR 100s-120s)
   -Cardiology has signed off, feel patient stable for any intervention
   that IP wishes.
   #Right eye injection/macular rash around orbit: Patient does describe
   pain in right eye, pain with movement of right eye, difficulty with
   vision out of right eye. Patient was seen by ID & opthomology at OSH,
   initially on Acyclovir, but optho felt that not consistent with
   herpetic eye involvement, most likely chronic conjunctival chemosis.
   Currently no vesicular rash around eye so nothing to biopsy.

   # Facial twitching: Appeared as though this may have been a possible

   context of RIJ pull. Will continue to monitor for further signs of

   -EEG

   #Anasarca: Patient was receiving diuresis at OSH; received up to Lasix
   80mg IV BID, then changed to Bumex, which was then d/c'd for
   hypotension. Patient
s weight on admission (presumably dry weight) was
   62 kg. [**Month (only) 51**] be preload dependent given degree of hypotension experienced
   with Lasix.
   -D/c lasix for now as patient appears to be tolerating this poorly,
   becoming tachycardic and hypotensive.
   -Will try to keep patient mildly net negative each day
   #.Leukocytosis: patient was transfered on multiple antibiotics for
   several infections he experienced during 2 months at OSH. At this time,
   he has been taken off all antibiotics, and has been afebrile. However,
   does have mild leukcocytosis (11.8). Will continue to monitor. Sputum
   culture shows  >25 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field, as well as
   1+ gram neg rods. [**Month (only) 51**] represent colonization with pseudomonas given his
   trach. Will plan to treat if patient becomes febrile. Patient also has

   -Monitor fever curve

   -Stool for C.diff

   parasitic infection given recent travel to [**Country **]; may be secondary
   to medication.
   -Stool for O&P x3
   -AM cortisol
   -Minimize unecassary medications (d/c
d antibiotics, PPI, diuretics,

   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased ferritin.
   Patient also receiving frequent blood draws which may be contributing

   patient had multiple attempts at central line placement yesterday).

Summary:

The patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including COPD, who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and possible stenting of tracheobronchomalacia. Overnight, the patient has been tachycardic and hypotensive, and a total fluid bolus of 750 mL was given. The patient has a history of multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from the ventilator, and s/p trach and PEG placement.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is failing to wean from the ventilator. The possibility of tracheobronchomalacia and bronchiectasis is high, which may be contributing to his respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient has elevated troponins, which may indicate cardiac ischemia or infarction. The patient is also atrial-paced at a rate of 90 bpm, which may indicate demand ischemia.
3. Eye Complications: The patient has a macular rash around his orbit and eye pain, which may be related to chronic conjunctival chemosis or herpes simplex.
4. Seizure Activity: The patient had a possible seizure episode, which may be related to air embolus or other underlying medical conditions.
5. Anasarca: The patient has edema, which may be related to chronic malnutrition and dehydration.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient has mild leukocytosis, which may be related to colonization with pseudomonas or other underlying medical conditions.
7. Eosinophilia: The patient has eosinophilia, which may be related to adrenal insufficiency, parasitic infection, or medication.
8. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may be related to chronic disease, iron deficiency, or frequent blood draws.
9. Elevated Alkaline Phosphatase: The patient has elevated alkaline phosphatase, which may be related to shock liver or chronic bedbound state.
10. Hypokalemia: The patient has hypokalemia, which may be related to potassium loss or inadequate replacement.
11. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which may be related to inadequate free water replacement.
12. Decreased Albumin: The patient has decreased albumin, which may be related to chronic malnutrition or liver disease.
13. Ulcers: The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers, which may be related to prolonged bedrest and malnutrition.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Consult cardiology to further evaluate the patient's cardiac status and consider further cardiac testing.
3. Consult ophthalmology to further evaluate the patient's eye condition and plan for management.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's seizure activity and consider further testing, such as EEG.
5. Monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust diuretic therapy as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's leukocytosis and plan for further testing and treatment as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's eosinophilia and plan for further testing and treatment as needed.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and plan for further testing and treatment as needed.
9. Monitor the patient's alkaline phosphatase levels and plan for further testing and treatment as needed.
10. Monitor the patient's potassium and sodium levels and adjust replacement therapy as needed.
11. Continue to monitor the patient's albumin levels and plan for further testing and treatment as needed.
12. Continue to monitor the patient's wound status and plan for further treatment and management as needed.

Note: The patient's complex medical history and multiple comorbidities require a multidisciplinary approach to care, involving multiple specialists and consultants.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and possible tracheobronchomalacia. He has a long hospital course with multiple complications, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), failure to wean from the ventilator, and tracheostomy placement. He was sent from the operating room (OSH) for further evaluation and management.

Current status:

The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and has a tracheostomy tube in place. He has a central line and a multi-lumen catheter in place. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.9°C, heart rate of 117 bpm, and blood pressure of 114/63 mmHg. He has a mild leukocytosis and an elevated troponin level, which is being monitored.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for further respiratory failure.
2. Seizure: The patient had a presumed seizure episode, and EEG is pending.
3. Cardiac issues: The patient has elevated troponin levels and is at risk for cardiac complications, including demand ischemia.
4. Infection: The patient has a mild leukocytosis and an elevated troponin level, which may indicate an infection.
5. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease, and his hemoglobin level is decreasing.
6. Eosinophilia: The patient has eosinophilia, which may be secondary to adrenal insufficiency, parasitic infection, or medication.
7. Anasarca: The patient has edema, which may be secondary to chronic heart failure or nephrotic syndrome.
8. Decubitus ulcers: The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers, which require wound care and optimization of nutrition.
9. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which requires free water flushes via PEG.
10. Hypokalemia: The patient has hypokalemia, which requires potassium repletion.

Plan:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor respiratory status.
2. Monitor cardiac status and consider cardiology consultation.
3. Monitor infection status and consider antibiotic therapy.
4. Optimize nutrition and monitor anemia.
5. Manage eosinophilia and consider parasitic infection or adrenal insufficiency.
6. Manage anasarca and consider diuretic therapy.
7. Provide wound care and optimize nutrition for decubitus ulcers.
8. Manage hypernatremia and hypokalemia.
9. Consider EP consultation for possible demand ischemia.
10. Monitor and adjust medications as necessary.

   - formal airway CT

   No further episodes overnight.
   - EEG pending
   - CT head

   require emergent cardiac catheterization. Possible demand ischemia, in
   setting of tachycardia and hypotension.   Beta blocker started
   yesterday.  Lipids normal.
   -Continue ASA

   consult
   #. Leukocytosis: Afebrile off all antibiotics with mild leukocytosis
   but trending down, sputum culture shows  2 species GNR.  Colonization
   vs infection. Patient also has significant history of diarrhea, C. diff
   neg.  With central line from OSH.
   - PICC today, pull SC and send tip for Cx.
   -Monitor fever curve, treat if becomes febrile

   hypotension. Patient
s weight on admission (presumably dry weight) was

   - Will try to keep patient mildly net negative each day

   travel to [**Country **],  may be secondary to parasitic infection.  Also
   concern for drug reaction
   -Stool for O&P x3
   -[**Last Name (un) **] Stim test
   -Minimize unecassary medications (d/c
d antibiotics, PPI, diuretics,

   #. Anemia: Hct stable, likely anemia of chronic disease given long
   hospital course; iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and
   increased ferritin.
   -Guiaic stools

   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Patient does describe pain

   was seen by ID & opthomology at OSH, initially on Acyclovir, but optho
   felt that not consistent with herpetic eye involvement, most likely

   - increase free water flushes via PEG to 150 ml q4hr

   chronically malnourished given long hospital course. Tube feeds via PEG

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including COPD, who was admitted to the ICU for assessment and management of respiratory failure, suspected tracheobronchomalacia, and possible stenting. He had a brief episode of altered responsiveness with right-sided twitching, which was evaluated as a possible seizure or air embolism. The patient's current condition is stable, and he is being managed for respiratory failure, seizure activity, elevated troponins, leukocytosis, anasarca, eosinophilia, anemia, and other comorbidities.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and he is at risk for further deterioration, especially if he develops pneumonia or other respiratory complications.
2. Seizure Activity: The patient's seizure episode is still under investigation, and he is at risk for further seizures, especially if his electrolyte levels are not closely monitored.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's elevated troponins and tachycardia suggest possible cardiac ischemia, which may require further evaluation and management.
4. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and positive sputum cultures suggest possible infection, which may require further antibiotic therapy and monitoring.
5. Anasarca: The patient's fluid overload and anasarca increase his risk for further complications, such as respiratory distress and cardiac failure.
6. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may be a sign of an underlying parasitic infection or allergic reaction, which requires further evaluation and management.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be related to his chronic disease or malnutrition, which requires further evaluation and management.
8. Wound Complications: The patient's decubitus ulcers and pressure ulcers increase his risk for further complications, such as infection and sepsis.
9. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition and anasarca increase his risk for further complications, such as respiratory distress and cardiac failure.
10. Medication Reactions: The patient's eosinophilia and anemia may be related to medication reactions, which requires further evaluation and management.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's seizure activity and adjust his anticonvulsant therapy as needed.
3. Evaluate the patient's cardiac status further, including echocardiogram and stress test, to determine the cause of his elevated troponins.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's infection status, including blood and urine cultures, and adjust his antibiotic therapy as needed.
5. Continue to manage the patient's anasarca and fluid overload, including diuretic therapy and fluid restriction.
6. Evaluate the patient's eosinophilia further, including stool and blood tests, to determine the cause of his eosinophilia.
7. Continue to manage the patient's anemia, including iron supplements and blood transfusions as needed.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's wound status and adjust his wound care therapy as needed.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust his nutrition therapy as needed.
10. Evaluate the patient's medication regimen further, including potential medication reactions, and adjust his medications as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for assessment and management of respiratory failure, seizure, and possible tracheobronchomalacia.

The patient's 24-hour events include a brief episode of altered responsiveness with right-sided twitching, which was concerning for seizure or air embolism. The patient's EEG is pending, and IgE levels are being evaluated for possible Aspergillosis.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, elevated troponins, and eosinophilia. His respiratory support includes continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation (SIMV). His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 110 bpm, and blood pressure of 115/61 mmHg.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD and tracheobronchomalacia increase the risk of respiratory failure, which may require mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
2. Seizure recurrence: The patient's seizure episode may recur, requiring further evaluation and management.
3. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and eosinophilia may indicate an underlying infection, such as pneumonia or sinusitis, which may require antibiotic therapy.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins may indicate cardiac injury or ischemia, which may require further evaluation and management.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, requiring blood transfusions and further evaluation.
6. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition may worsen, requiring nutritional support and optimization.
7. Pressure ulcers: The patient's pressure ulcers may worsen, requiring wound care and frequent repositioning.
8. Aspergillosis: The patient's possible Aspergillosis may require antifungal therapy and further evaluation.
9. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's eosinophilia and cortisol level may indicate adrenal insufficiency, which may require further evaluation and management.

To manage these potential complications, the patient's care plan includes:

1. Respiratory support: Continue CPAP and SIMV, and consider flexible bronchoscopy to evaluate tracheobronchomalacia.
2. Seizure management: Monitor for seizure recurrence, and consider anticonvulsant therapy if necessary.
3. Infection management: Monitor for signs of infection, and consider antibiotic therapy if necessary.
4. Cardiac management: Continue to monitor cardiac enzymes, and consider further evaluation and management if necessary.
5. Anemia management: Monitor hemoglobin levels, and consider blood transfusions if necessary.
6. Malnutrition management: Optimize nutrition, and consider tube feeds via PEG tube.
7. Pressure ulcer management: Continue wound care, frequent repositioning, and consider wound care consult.
8. Aspergillosis management: Monitor IgE levels, and consider antifungal therapy if necessary.
9. Adrenal insufficiency management: Monitor cortisol levels, and consider further evaluation and management if necessary.

In conclusion, the patient's complex medical condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and optimize outcomes.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory failure, seizure, and suspected tracheobronchomalacia. The patient has undergone multiple hospitalizations, including a previous stay at OSH, where he developed ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and was treated with antibiotics, which were discontinued.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube and is receiving oxygen therapy. His respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and his partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) is 100%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has tachycardia, with a heart rate of 113 beats per minute, and hypotension, with a blood pressure of 108/56 mmHg. His troponin levels are elevated, but he does not have any signs of cardiac failure.
* Neurological status: The patient had a presumed seizure, but no further episodes have occurred. His electroencephalogram (EEG) is pending.
* Hematological status: The patient has leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 11.8 x 10^9/L, and eosinophilia, with an eosinophil count of 14%. His platelet count is 336 x 10^9/L.
* Renal status: The patient's creatinine level is 0.7 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 24 mg/dL.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has diarrhea and has been colonized with Candida species. His liver function tests are normal.
* Nutritional status: The patient is receiving tube feeds via a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube, and his prealbumin level is pending.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further respiratory support.
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and elevated troponin levels may indicate sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's cortisol level is low, and he may require further evaluation and treatment for adrenal insufficiency.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 9.5 g/dL, and he may require further evaluation and treatment for anemia.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's albumin level is low, and he may require further evaluation and treatment for malnutrition.
6. Wound complications: The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers, which can lead to further complications, such as infection and sepsis.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, and he may require further evaluation and treatment for hypernatremia.
8. Hypokalemia: The patient's potassium level is low, and he may require further evaluation and treatment for hypokalemia.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, and further evaluation and treatment are necessary to manage his condition and prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old man with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure. He has undergone several procedures, including tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement, and has been on mechanical ventilation. He has also been diagnosed with possible tracheobronchomalacia and aspergillosis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: He is on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube in place. His respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 100% on 30% FiO2.
* Cardiovascular status: He has elevated troponins, which are stable, and is being monitored for possible demand ischemia. His blood pressure is 108/56 mmHg, and his heart rate is 113 beats per minute.
* Neurological status: He has had a seizure, and an electroencephalogram (EEG) is pending.
* Renal status: He has mild leukocytosis, and his urine output is 2,325 mL over the past 24 hours.
* Gastrointestinal status: He has been receiving tube feeds via his PEG tube and has a stage III decubitus ulcer on his sacrum/coccyx and a stage IV ulcer on his left ear helix.
* Hematological status: He has anemia of chronic disease, and his iron studies are consistent with this diagnosis.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk for further respiratory failure.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins and tachycardia suggest possible cardiac complications, such as demand ischemia.
* Neurological complications: The patient's seizure and elevated troponins suggest possible neurological complications, such as stroke or encephalitis.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's tube feeds and decubitus ulcers suggest possible gastrointestinal complications, such as tube feed intolerance or pressure ulcers.
* Hematological complications: The patient's anemia of chronic disease and elevated troponins suggest possible hematological complications, such as bleeding or blood clotting disorders.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as necessary.
* Consider performing a flexible bronchoscopy to evaluate the patient's airway and diagnose possible tracheobronchomalacia.
* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his beta blocker therapy as necessary.
* Consider performing an electroencephalogram (EEG) to evaluate the patient's neurological status.
* Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust his tube feeds and nutrition as necessary.
* Consider performing a wound care consult to evaluate the patient's decubitus ulcers and develop a plan for their management.
* Continue to monitor the patient's hematological status and adjust his iron therapy as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure and suspected tracheobronchomalacia. He had a previous hospital course at another institution, where he developed ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and failed to wean from the ventilator. He was sent to our institution for further evaluation and possible stenting of his airway.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: He is on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube and is receiving CPAP/PSV mode. His respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 100% on 30% FiO2.
* Cardiovascular status: He has elevated troponins, but no cardiac ischemia or infarction is suspected. He is tachycardic and has hypotension, which is being managed with beta blockers and fluids.
* Neurological status: He is presumed to have had a seizure, but no further episodes have occurred. An EEG is pending.
* Gastrointestinal status: He has a history of diarrhea and is colonized with Candida, but C. diff is negative. He has a central line infection, and his urine culture is positive for yeast.
* Hematological status: He has leukocytosis, which is trending down. He has anemia of chronic disease, and his iron studies are consistent with this diagnosis.
* Renal status: He is oliguric, and his creatinine is elevated.
* Electrolyte status: He is hypernatremic, and his potassium levels are low.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk for further deterioration.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension require close monitoring and management.
3. Seizure recurrence: The patient's presumed seizure requires further evaluation, and he is at risk for further seizures.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of diarrhea and colonization with Candida puts him at risk for further gastrointestinal complications.
5. Hematological complications: The patient's leukocytosis and anemia of chronic disease require close monitoring.
6. Renal complications: The patient's oliguria and elevated creatinine require close monitoring and management.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's hypernatremia and hypokalemia require close monitoring and management.
8. Wound complications: The patient's stage III and IV decubitus ulcers require close monitoring and management.

Plan:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode.
2. Monitor and manage the patient's cardiovascular status, including tachycardia and hypotension.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status, including EEG and CT head.
4. Manage the patient's gastrointestinal status, including diarrhea and colonization with Candida.
5. Monitor and manage the patient's hematological status, including leukocytosis and anemia of chronic disease.
6. Monitor and manage the patient's renal status, including oliguria and elevated creatinine.
7. Monitor and manage the patient's electrolyte status, including hypernatremia and hypokalemia.
8. Continue to monitor and manage the patient's wound status, including decubitus ulcers.
9. Consider flexible bronchoscopy once medically stabilized.
10. Plan for weaning from the ventilator once the patient's respiratory status improves.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including COPD, who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and possible stenting of tracheobronchomalacia. The patient's condition has been complex, with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from the ventilator, and tracheostomy placement.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient remains on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, with a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 100%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a tachycardia with a heart rate of 113 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 108/56 mmHg. The patient has been started on beta-blocker therapy and has a stable troponin level.
* Hematological: The patient has leukocytosis, with a WBC count of 11.8 x 10^9/L, and eosinophilia, with an eosinophil count of 14%.
* Renal: The patient has a creatinine level of 0.7 mg/dL and a BUN level of 24 mg/dL.
* Hepatic: The patient has an elevated alkaline phosphatase level of 187 IU/L, which is trending down.
* Nutritional: The patient is receiving tube feeds via PEG tube and has a prealbumin level of 0.6 mg/dL.
* Wound care: The patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on left ear helix, which requires wound care consult and optimization of nutrition.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and there is a risk of further respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may indicate cardiac ischemia or other cardiac complications.
3. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and eosinophilia may indicate an underlying infection, and the patient's history of diarrhea and colonization with GNR bacteria may increase the risk of infection.
4. Malnutrition: The patient's chronic malnutrition and decreased albumin level may increase the risk of further complications, such as pressure ulcers and wound infections.
5. Wound complications: The patient's stage III and IV decubitus ulcers may lead to further complications, such as infection, cellulitis, or osteomyelitis.

In summary, the patient remains a complex case with multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications and optimize the patient's outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and sepsis. He has a tracheostomy tube and is on mechanical ventilation. He has a history of multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from the ventilator, and stenting of tracheobronchomalacia.

The patient's current condition is stable, with a temperature of 100.3°F, tachycardia, and hypotension. He has a white blood cell count of 11.8, which is trending down. He has a history of diarrhea and C. diff negative, and is currently receiving Lasix for fluid management.

The patient's medications include furosemide, heparin, and prednisone. He is also receiving tube feeds via PEG tube.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is at risk for further respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or tracheobronchomalacia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's temperature is elevated, and he has a history of sepsis. He is at risk for further septic episodes, particularly if his infection is not adequately managed.
3. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient has a positive corticotropin stimulation test, which suggests adrenal insufficiency. He is receiving prednisone therapy to manage this condition.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which may be a sign of infection or inflammation.
5. Anasarca: The patient has significant edema, particularly in his upper extremities. He is at risk for further fluid accumulation, particularly if his Lasix therapy is not adequately managed.
6. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophil count is elevated, which may be a sign of an allergic reaction or parasitic infection.
7. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, which may be due to chronic disease or malnutrition.
8. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient has a history of eye pain and vision difficulties, which may be related to chronic conjunctival chemosis.
9. Elevated alk phos: The patient's alkaline phosphatase level is elevated, which may be due to liver dysfunction or other causes.
10. Hypokalemia: The patient's potassium level is low, which may be due to diuretic therapy or other causes.
11. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, which may be due to fluid management or other causes.
12. Decreased albumin: The patient's albumin level is low, which may be due to malnutrition or other causes.
13. Ulcers: The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers, which may be due to pressure or other causes.
14. FEN: The patient is receiving tube feeds via PEG tube, which may be a risk factor for further complications, such as aspiration or malnutrition.

Based on this information, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, and metabolic status. He also requires further evaluation and management of his potential complications, such as adrenal insufficiency, leukocytosis, anasarca, eosinophilia, anemia, right eye injection/macular orbital rash, elevated alk phos, hypokalemia, hypernatremia, decreased albumin, and ulcers.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and has been hospitalized for several weeks with multiple complications, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), failure to wean from the ventilator, and tracheobronchomalacia. The patient was recently transferred to the ICU from another hospital for further evaluation and management.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube and is being weaned off the ventilator. The patient has a history of bronchiectasis and tracheobronchomalacia.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has elevated troponins, but no cardiac problems have been identified. The patient has a history of tachycardia and hypotension, and is being treated with beta blockers to manage demand ischemia.
* Neurological status: The patient had a presumed seizure, but no further episodes have occurred. An EEG is pending, and the patient is being monitored for further seizures.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has diarrhea, and C. difficile testing has been negative. The patient has a history of eosinophilia, which has resolved. The patient is being treated with prednisone for adrenal insufficiency.
* Hematological status: The patient has leukocytosis, which is trending down. The patient has anemia, which is likely related to chronic disease.
* Renal status: The patient has hypernatremia, which is being managed with free water flushes. The patient's electrolyte levels are pending.
* Nutritional status: The patient is receiving tube feeds via a PEG tube.
* Wound care: The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers, and is being treated with wound care consults and frequent repositioning.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and further respiratory failure could occur if the patient is not weaned off the ventilator successfully.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins and tachycardia suggest potential cardiac problems, and further cardiac complications could occur if not managed appropriately.
* Neurological complications: The patient's presumed seizure and ongoing neurological monitoring suggest potential neurological complications, such as further seizures or neurological decline.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diarrhea and history of eosinophilia suggest potential gastrointestinal complications, such as further gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.
* Hematological complications: The patient's anemia and leukocytosis suggest potential hematological complications, such as further bleeding or infection.
* Renal complications: The patient's hypernatremia suggests potential renal complications, such as further electrolyte imbalances or kidney damage.
* Wound care complications: The patient's decubitus ulcers suggest potential wound care complications, such as further tissue damage or infection.

The patient's medical team should continue to monitor the patient's condition closely and address any potential complications that arise.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with multiple complications, including respiratory failure, seizure, elevated troponins, adrenal insufficiency, leukocytosis, anasarca, eosinophilia, anemia, and ulcers.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 97%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has elevated troponins, which are trending down, and is being treated with metoprolol 37.5 mg TID. The patient's heart rate is 103 beats per minute, and blood pressure is 88/44 mmHg.
* Neurological status: The patient had a presumed seizure, but subsequent EEG showed no epileptiform activity, and the patient has been treated with prednisone 5mg PO daily.
* Infectious disease status: The patient has a positive sputum culture for pseudomonas, and a gram stain from yesterday continues positive for GNR. The patient's leukocytosis is trending down, and the patient has been treated with antibiotics.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has a stage III decubitus ulcer on the sacrum/coccyx, and a stage IV ulcer on the left ear helix. The patient is receiving tube feeds via PEG tube, and has a history of diarrhea, which is currently under control.
* Renal status: The patient's creatinine level is 0.6 mg/dL, and the patient is receiving lasix gtt for diuresis.
* Hematological status: The patient has anemia, which is likely due to the chronic disease, and is being treated with prednisone 5mg PO daily.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is precarious, and the patient may require further interventions to improve oxygenation and ventilation.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins and tachycardia may indicate cardiac ischemia or infarction, and the patient may require further cardiac evaluation and treatment.
* Infectious complications: The patient's positive sputum culture and gram stain may indicate a serious infection, and the patient may require further antibiotics and treatment.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's decubitus ulcers and history of diarrhea may indicate gastrointestinal compromise, and the patient may require further wound care and nutritional support.
* Renal complications: The patient's creatinine level may indicate renal impairment, and the patient may require further evaluation and treatment to prevent further kidney damage.

In summary, the patient is a high-risk patient with multiple comorbidities, and the patient's condition is precarious. The patient requires close monitoring and further evaluation to prevent potential complications and improve the patient's outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further evaluation and management.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has a history of COPD and was previously ventilator-dependent. He is currently receiving mechanical ventilation, and his respiratory status is being closely monitored.
2. Seizure: The patient had a presumed seizure episode, and an electroencephalogram (EEG) showed no epileptiform activity, consistent with encephalopathy.
3. Elevated troponins: The patient's troponin levels are elevated, likely due to demand ischemia, and he is being managed with metoprolol.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient has been diagnosed with adrenal insufficiency, and is receiving prednisone therapy.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient has a leukocytosis, which is trending down, and he is being monitored for signs of infection.
6. Anasarca: The patient has significant edema, which is being managed with diuretics.
7. Eosinophilia: The patient has an eosinophilia, which is likely secondary to adrenal insufficiency, and is being monitored for signs of eosinophilic disorders.
8. Anemia: The patient has an anemia of chronic disease, and is being monitored for signs of bleeding.
9. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient has a chronic conjunctival chemosis, and is being monitored for signs of herpetic eye involvement.
10. Decreased albumin: The patient has a decreased albumin level, which is likely due to chronic malnutrition, and is being monitored for signs of malnutrition.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and any further deterioration could lead to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins and demand ischemia make him at risk for cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or arrhythmias.
3. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and eosinophilia make him at risk for infection, particularly in the setting of his chronic medical conditions.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency requires careful management to prevent adrenal crisis.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's decreased albumin level and anemia make him at risk for malnutrition, which could exacerbate his underlying medical conditions.

The patient's care plan should focus on:

1. Close monitoring of his respiratory status and cardiac function.
2. Aggressive management of his adrenal insufficiency and anemia.
3. Prevention and treatment of infections, including antibiotic stewardship and wound care.
4. Optimization of his nutrition, including tube feeds and free water flushes.
5. Frequent repositioning to prevent pressure ulcers.
6. Management of his eosinophilia and potential eosinophilic disorders.
7. Close communication with the patient's family and primary care physician to ensure coordinated care.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has a history of COPD, and his condition has deteriorated, leading to respiratory failure. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.
2. Seizure: The patient had a presumed seizure episode, and his EEG report shows no epileptiform activity, but further evaluation is pending.
3. Elevated Troponins: The patient's troponin levels are elevated, indicating possible demand ischemia. He is being managed medically, but further evaluation is needed to rule out cardiac issues.
4. Adrenal Insufficiency: The patient's cortisotropin syn test is positive for adrenal insufficiency, and he is receiving prednisone therapy.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which may be related to infection or inflammation. His sputum culture is positive for Pseudomonas, and his urine culture is pending.
6. Anasarca: The patient has fluid overload, which is being managed with diuretics. He has a history of VAP and may have developed anasarca as a result.
7. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may be secondary to adrenal insufficiency or a parasitic infection. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause.
8. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease, which is likely related to his long hospital course.
9. Right Eye Injection/Macular Orbital Rash: The patient has a painful eye condition that may be related to chronic conjunctival chemosis. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause.
10. Decreased Albumin: The patient has decreased albumin levels, which may be related to chronic malnutrition. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause.
11. Ulcers: The patient has multiple stage III and IV pressure ulcers, which require wound care and optimization of nutrition.

The patient's condition is complex, and further evaluation and management are needed to address these potential complications.

   ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  Bronch at OSH with
   ?tracheobronchomalacia.  From OSH ?Aspergillus in sputum, ?ABPA. Per
   family report, patient using home O2 for less than one month prior to
   going to hospital, seems he was not that limited by COPD prior to most
   recent hospitalization. CT showed b/l pleural effusions, small/mod on
   right, small on left, diffuse mild bronchial wall thickening and small
   clusters of centrilobular nodules and peribronchovascular ground glass
   opacities suggesting recent infection/inflammation or possibly
   aspiration. No radiologic evidence of TBM.
   -IP following
   -f/u IgE levels Aspergillus
   - wean from vent
   #. Seizure: Presumed seizure since he was unresponsive and twitching.
   No further episodes. EEG initial report shows no epileptiform activity,
   diffuse slowing consistent with encephalopathy
   - EEG pending
   - CT head
   #. Elevated troponins: No CP; cardiology saw him on arrival, feel does
   not require emergent cardiac catheterization, recommend medical
   management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of tachycardia and
   hypotension.   Troponin elevated yesterday to 0.59, metoprolol was
   increased out of concern for likely demand ischemia. Continues
   tachycardic, slightly improved.
   -Continue ASA
   -When HR decreased so that pacer spikes can be viewed consider EP
   consult
   -Check troponin again and EKG
   -Continue Metoprolol 37.5 TID
   #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency
   -Prednisone 5mg PO daily
   #. Leukocytosis: Trending down still. Patient febrile yesterday to
   101.1, pancultured. No growth to date from any blood or urine.  Sputum
   culture + for pseudomonas; sputum gram stain from yesterday continues +
   for GNR. Colonization vs infection. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   -SC tip pending
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Anasarca: Patient was receiving diuresis at OSH; received up to
   Lasix 80mg IV BID, then changed to Bumex, which was then d/c'd for
   hypotension. Patient
s weight on admission to OSH (presumably dry
   weight) was 62 kg.  No occlusive DVT in upper extremities. On lasix gtt
   for most of yesterday, net negative significantly but then became
   hypotensive.
   -Restart lasix gtt this am, very gentle diuresis
   - Will try to keep patient mildly net negative each day
   #. Eosinophilia: Presented to OSH with eosinophilia which normalized,
   then at presentation to [**Hospital1 19**] at 14%. Now trending down to 8% on
   prednisone, most likely  eosinophilia secondary to adrenal
   insufficiency. Recent travel to [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be secondary to
   parasitic infection; however, O&P neg TD.  Also concern for drug
   reaction
   -Minimize unecassary medications (d/c
d antibiotics, PPI, diuretics,

   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Anemia: Hct stable, likely anemia of chronic disease given long
   hospital course; iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and

   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Patient does describe pain

   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on

   -Wound care consult

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history, including COPD, who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, seizure, elevated troponins, adrenal insufficiency, leukocytosis, anasarca, eosinophilia, anemia, right eye injection/macular orbital rash, decreased albumin, and ulcers.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has COPD and was s/p trach for failure to wean from the ventilator. The CT scan showed bilateral pleural effusions, diffuse mild bronchial wall thickening, and small clusters of centrilobular nodules and peribronchovascular ground glass opacities.
* Seizure: The patient had a presumed seizure, but EEG initial report showed no epileptiform activity, and the patient has been seizure-free since.
* Elevated troponins: The patient's troponin levels were elevated, and cardiology recommended medical management, possibly due to demand ischemia.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's cortisotropin syn test was positive for adrenal insufficiency, and he is receiving prednisone 5mg PO daily.
* Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is trending down, and he is febrile with a temperature of 101.1. His sputum culture is positive for pseudomonas, and his sputum gram stain is positive for GNR.
* Anasarca: The patient has been receiving diuresis, but his weight remains high, and he has a net negative balance. He is at risk for developing further edema.
* Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophil count is trending down, and he is receiving prednisone for adrenal insufficiency.
* Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is stable, and he is likely anemic due to chronic disease.
* Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient has a painful right eye with difficulty with vision, and he is being treated with prednisone.
* Decreased albumin: The patient's albumin level is low, and he is chronically malnourished.
* Ulcers: The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers, and he is at risk for further pressure damage.

The potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD and respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further respiratory distress.
* Seizure: The patient may experience further seizures, especially if his troponin levels remain elevated.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency can worsen, leading to further symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and low blood pressure.
* Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis can worsen, leading to further infection and sepsis.
* Anasarca: The patient's anasarca can worsen, leading to further edema and respiratory distress.
* Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia can worsen, leading to further symptoms such as skin rash, itching, and difficulty breathing.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen, leading to further symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
* Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient's right eye infection can worsen, leading to further vision loss and potentially even blindness.
* Decreased albumin: The patient's decreased albumin can worsen, leading to further malnutrition and weakness.
* Ulcers: The patient's ulcers can worsen, leading to further pain, infection, and potentially even sepsis.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Respiratory support: The patient is receiving oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation.
* Medications: The patient is receiving various medications, including prednisone, metoprolol, and heparin.
* Wound care: The patient's wounds are being treated with dressing changes and antibiotics.
* Nutrition: The patient is receiving tube feeds via PEG tube and free water flushes.
* Pain management: The patient is receiving pain management with opioids and other medications.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.
   #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean from
   ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  Bronch at OSH with
   ?tracheobronchomalacia. . CT showed b/l pleural effusions, small/mod on
   right, small on left, diffuse mild bronchial wall thickening and small
   clusters of centrilobular nodules and peribronchovascular ground glass
   opacities suggesting recent infection/inflammation or possibly
   aspiration. Most likely secondary to previous VAP at OSH. No radiologic
   evidence of TBM  From OSH ? Aspergillus in sputum, ?ABPA. Per family
   report, patient using home O2 for less than one month prior to going to
   hospital, seems he was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent
   hospitalization.
   -IP following, if definitively no stenting will inform pulmonologist at
   OSH
   -f/u IgE levels Aspergillus
   - wean from vent
   #. Seizure: Presumed seizure since he was unresponsive and twitching.
   No further episodes. EEG initial report shows no epileptiform activity,
   diffuse slowing consistent with encephalopathy
   - EEG pending
   - CT head
   #. Elevated troponins: No CP; cardiology saw him on arrival, feel does
   not require emergent cardiac catheterization, recommend medical
   management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of tachycardia and
   hypotension.   Troponin elevated yesterday to 0.59, metoprolol was
   increased out of concern for likely demand ischemia. Also may have poor
   renal function without elevated creatinine in the setting of very
   little muscle mass. Continues tachycardic, slightly improved.
   -Continue ASA
   -When HR decreased so that pacer spikes can be viewed consider EP
   consult
   -Check troponin again and EKG
   -Continue Metoprolol 37.5 TID
   -If troponins trending up will get cardiology consult
   #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency
   -Prednisone 5mg PO daily
   #. Leukocytosis: Trending down still. Patient febrile yesterday to
   101.1, pancultured. No growth to date from any blood or urine.  Sputum
   culture + for pseudomonas; sputum gram stain from yesterday continues +
   for GNR. Colonization vs infection. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   -SC tip pending
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Anasarca: Patient was receiving diuresis at OSH; received up to
   Lasix 80mg IV BID, then changed to Bumex, which was then d/c'd for
   hypotension. Patient
s weight on admission to OSH (presumably dry
   weight) was 62 kg.  No occlusive DVT in upper extremities. On lasix gtt
   for most of yesterday, net negative significantly but then became
   hypotensive.
   -Restart lasix gtt this am, very gentle diuresis
   - Will try to keep patient mildly net negative each day (goal for
   today: -500mL)
   #. Eosinophilia: Presented to OSH with eosinophilia which normalized,
   then at presentation to [**Hospital1 19**] at 14%. Now trending down to 8% on
   prednisone, most likely eosinophilia secondary to adrenal
   insufficiency. Recent travel to [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be secondary to
   parasitic infection; however, O&P neg TD.  Also concern for drug
   reaction
   -Minimize unecassary medications (d/c
d antibiotics, PPI, diuretics,
   betablocker)
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Anemia: Hct stable, likely anemia of chronic disease given long
   hospital course; iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and
   increased ferritin.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Patient does describe pain
   in right eye, pain with movement, and difficulty with vision. Patient
   was seen by ID & opthomology at OSH, initially on Acyclovir, but optho
   felt that not consistent with herpetic eye involvement, most likely
   chronic conjunctival chemosis. Currently no vesicular rash around eye
   so nothing to biopsy.
   -Consider ophtho consult
   #Decreased albumin: Measuring prealbumin. Patient most likely
   chronically malnourished given long hospital course. Tube feeds via PEG
   tube, f/u prealbumin.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].
   -Wound care consult
   -Optimize nutrition
   -Frequent repositioning
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchiectasis, and a recent hospitalization at OSH with multiple complications, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure and requires mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.5°C, heart rate of 95 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 115/54 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 98% on 30% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2).

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated troponin level, which is being managed with medical therapy. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows no acute changes. He has also been diagnosed with adrenal insufficiency and is receiving cortisone therapy.

The patient's infectious disease workup is ongoing, with positive cultures for Pseudomonas aeruginosa in his sputum and yeast in his urine. He has been treated with antibiotics, but the cultures remain positive.

The patient's nutritional status is compromised, with a prealbumin level of 19 (21-43) mg/dL. He is receiving tube feeds via a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube.

The patient has multiple pressure ulcers, including stage III decubitus ulcers on his sacrum and coccyx and stage IV ulcers on his left ear helix. He also has a circular healed pressure ulcer on his right post-acromium process.

The patient's code status is full code, and his emergency contact is his daughter, who lives with his mother and is aware of his wishes.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to continue, and he may require ongoing mechanical ventilation.
2. Infection: The patient's positive cultures for Pseudomonas aeruginosa and yeast suggest that he is at risk for further infections, which may require antibiotic therapy.
3. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency may require ongoing cortisone therapy to manage his symptoms.
4. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's elevated troponin level and history of cardiac disease suggest that he may be at risk for further cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction or arrhythmias.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's compromised nutritional status may require ongoing nutritional support to prevent further deficiencies.
6. Pressure ulcer progression: The patient's pressure ulcers may worsen if he is not properly turned and repositioned, which may lead to further complications, such as infection or sepsis.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's tube feeds may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as diarrhea or constipation, which may require further management.

In summary, the patient is a high-risk individual with multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, infection, adrenal insufficiency, cardiovascular disease, and nutritional deficiencies. He requires ongoing medical therapy and close monitoring to prevent further complications.
