 ELECTROLYTE & FLUID DISORDER, OTHER
 .H/O RESPIRATORY FAILURE, CHRONIC
 ALTERATION IN NUTRITION
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
 IMPAIRED SKIN INTEGRITY
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.
    #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean
   from ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.  Has
   been tolerating trach mask well
   -Will continue to wean from vent, currently on PSV 5/5 with 30% FiO2.
    #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs.
   - Continues on Prednisone 5mg PO daily for now but will need to touch
   base with Endocrine about this dosage
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Anasarca: Improved, though he continues to have UE>LE edema.  An
   ultrasound was negative for an obstructive clot.
   --Goal today is negative as blood pressure can tolerate
   --Is only slightly negative through [**Location 11298**] 40mg IV bid
   #. Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased ferritin.
   -Retic index 1.17 indicating hypoproliferation.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   # Tachycardic: Elevated troponins, no CP; cardiology saw him on
   arrival, felt he did not require emergent cardiac catheterization,
   recommend medical management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of
   tachycardia and hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to
   0.61.  Metoprolol was increased out of concern for likely demand
   ischemia.  Could have poor renal function without elevated creatinine
   in the setting of very little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 25mg PO q6
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile.  Has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine
   and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   #. EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be
   primary contact person, lives with mother and aware of wishes.
   #. DISPOSITION: Rehab as soon as bed available ?today

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure. He has undergone a tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient has multiple comorbidities, including adrenal insufficiency, anemia, chronic edema, and impaired skin integrity.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.4°C (99.3°F)
* Heart rate: 98 bpm (93-108 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 105/58 mmHg (69-131/76 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 24 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous pressure (CVP) and pulmonary artery catheter (PAC) are not mentioned.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 10.1 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 333 K/uL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 35 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Troponin: 0.61 ng/mL
* Electrolyte levels: sodium 140 mEq/L, potassium 4.7 mEq/L, magnesium 1.7 mg/dL, and phosphorus 0.6 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)
* Prednisone 5mg PO daily
* Metoprolol 25mg PO q6
* Pilocarpine (eye drops)
* Bacitracin and vigamox (eye drops)
* Ranitidine (ulcer prophylaxis)
* Tube feeds via PEG tube
* Free water flushes 250 cc q4

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient has been diagnosed with adrenal insufficiency, and his cortisol levels are being monitored.
2. Anemia: The patient has chronic anemia, likely due to the chronic disease, and is being treated with iron supplements.
3. Chronic edema: The patient has chronic edema, which is being managed with diuretics.
4. Impaired skin integrity: The patient has impaired skin integrity, which is being managed with wound care and frequent repositioning.
5. Tachycardia: The patient has tachycardia, which is being managed with metoprolol.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which is being monitored.
7. Eosinophilia: The patient has eosinophilia, which is being monitored.
8. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient has a rash, which is being managed with eye drops.
9. Ulcers: The patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on left ear helix, which are being managed with wound care and frequent repositioning.
10. Respiratory failure: The patient has respiratory failure, which is being managed with mechanical ventilation.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Weaning from mechanical ventilation
2. Managing adrenal insufficiency with cortisol replacement therapy
3. Managing anemia with iron supplements
4. Managing chronic edema with diuretics
5. Managing impaired skin integrity with wound care and frequent repositioning
6. Managing tachycardia with metoprolol
7. Monitoring leukocytosis and eosinophilia
8. Managing right eye injection/macular orbital rash with eye drops
9. Managing ulcers with wound care and frequent repositioning
10. Managing respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and weaning.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic anemia, chronic pleural effusion, and a recent hospitalization for respiratory failure. The patient is currently admitted to the ICU for further management.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 97 bpm, blood pressure of 102/53 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy through a tracheostomy tube and is on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 30%.

The patient has a history of adrenal insufficiency, which was confirmed by a corticotropin stimulation test. The patient is currently receiving prednisone 5mg PO daily, and the dose will need to be adjusted based on the results of the adrenal function tests.

The patient has anemia, which is likely due to chronic disease, and is being managed with daily hemoglobin and iron studies.

The patient has tachycardia, which is being managed with metoprolol 25mg PO q6. The patient's troponin levels are persistently elevated, suggesting possible demand ischemia.

The patient has leukocytosis, which is likely due to colonization with yeast and pseudomonas. The patient's central line has been removed, and no antibiotics are currently being given.

The patient has eosinophilia, which is thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency. The patient is receiving prednisone 5mg PO daily for adrenal insufficiency.

The patient has a macular orbital rash, which is likely due to blepharitis. The patient's eye drops have been changed to bacitracin and vigamox, which seems to be helping.

The patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on the sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on the left ear helix. The patient is being frequently repositioned and receiving wound care.

The patient's fluid balance is being closely monitored, with a goal of 1-1.5L negative. The patient is receiving lasix 40mg IV bid.

The patient's code status is full code, and the primary contact person is the patient's daughter, who lives with the patient's mother and is aware of the patient's wishes.

Potential medical complications that could arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal function tests are pending, and the dose of prednisone needs to be adjusted based on the results.
2. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic disease, and the patient will need to continue to receive iron studies and hemoglobin monitoring.
3. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is being managed with metoprolol, but the patient's troponin levels are persistently elevated, suggesting possible demand ischemia.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is likely due to colonization with yeast and pseudomonas, and the patient will need to continue to receive close monitoring for signs of infection.
5. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia is thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency, and the patient will need to continue to receive prednisone for adrenal insufficiency.
6. Skin integrity: The patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on the sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on the left ear helix, and the patient will need to continue to receive close monitoring and wound care.
7. Fluid balance: The patient's fluid balance is being closely monitored, and the patient will need to continue to receive close monitoring for signs of fluid overload or dehydration.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient has a history of respiratory failure and is currently receiving oxygen therapy through a tracheostomy tube. The patient will need to continue to receive close monitoring for signs of respiratory failure.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition and potential medical complications as follows:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), s/p long hospital course at OSH with multiple complications, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and failure to wean from the ventilator.
* The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, 30% FiO2, and PS 5 cmH2O.
* He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is being weaned from the ventilator.
* The patient has a history of anemia, chronic, likely anemia of chronic disease, and is receiving daily HCT and active T&S.
* He has elevated troponins, no CP, and is being managed medically for possible demand ischemia.
* The patient has leukocytosis, trending down, and has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely colonizers.
* He has eosinophilia, thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency, but still continues to be elevated.
* The patient has multiple skin ulcers, including stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on left ear helix, and is being managed with wound care and frequent repositioning.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD and history of VAP increase the risk of respiratory failure.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient has been diagnosed with adrenal insufficiency and is being managed with cortisone replacement therapy.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not properly managed.
* Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may indicate an underlying infection or inflammation.
* Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may indicate an allergic reaction or hypersensitivity reaction to medications.
* Skin ulcers: The patient's multiple skin ulcers increase the risk of infection, wound complications, and prolonged hospitalization.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may indicate a underlying electrolyte imbalance or dehydration.
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and electrolyte imbalance increase the risk of electrolyte and fluid disorder.

**Assessment and Plan:**

* The patient will continue to be weaned from the ventilator, and a trache mask trial will be attempted today.
* The patient will continue to receive cortisone replacement therapy for adrenal insufficiency.
* The patient's anemia will be managed with daily HCT and active T&S.
* The patient's leukocytosis will be monitored, and antibiotics will be started if infection is suspected.
* The patient's eosinophilia will be monitored, and medications will be minimized if possible.
* The patient's skin ulcers will be managed with wound care and frequent repositioning.
* The patient will be repositioned frequently to prevent pressure ulcers.
* The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder will be monitored, and electrolyte replacement therapy will be started if necessary.

Overall, the patient's complex medical condition and multiple comorbidities increase the risk of medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and manage these complications.

   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.
    #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean
   from ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.
   Patient did not tolerate trache mask trial well yesterday
   -Will continue to wean from vent, currently on PSV 5/5 with 30% FiO2.
   -Trache mask trial today, if patient does not tolerate well would get
   CXR to assess for possible worsening
    #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs, currently still pending
   - Continues on Prednisone 5mg PO daily per endocrine
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Anasarca: Improved.  An ultrasound was negative for an obstructive
   clot.  BUN and Cr stable, seem to be tolerating aggressive diuresis
   --Goal today is even/mildly negative
   --Lasix 40mg IV bid
   #. Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased
   ferritin.Retic index 1.17 indicating hypoproliferation.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   # Tachycardic: Elevated troponins, no CP; cardiology saw him on
   arrival, felt he did not require emergent cardiac catheterization,
   recommend medical management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of
   tachycardia and hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to
   0.61.  Metoprolol was increased out of concern for likely demand
   ischemia.  Could have poor renal function without elevated creatinine
   in the setting of very little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 25mg PO q6
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile. WBC count trending down.  Has had yeast
   and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely colonizers.
   Patient also has significant history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central
   line from OSH now pulled, no growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated, though trending down (today 7.1%). [**Month (only) 51**]
   be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.

   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

* The patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history of COPD, chronic respiratory failure, and multiple hospitalizations, including a recent admission to the operating room for possible stenting of tracheobronchomalacia.
* The patient is currently in the ICU, intubated, and receiving mechanical ventilation.
* The patient has a history of adrenal insufficiency, which was confirmed by a cortisotropin syn test. He is being treated with prednisone 5mg PO daily.
* The patient has anemia of chronic disease, likely due to his long hospital course. He is being monitored with daily HCT and is receiving active T&S.
* The patient has tachycardia and elevated troponins, which are being managed with metoprolol 25mg PO q6.
* The patient has leukocytosis, which is trending down. He has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely colonizers.
* The patient has eosinophilia, which may be due to adrenal insufficiency or medications. He is being monitored and managed accordingly.
* The patient has a right eye injection and macular orbital rash, which is being treated with bacitracin and vigamox.
* The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers, which are being managed with wound care and frequent repositioning.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has a history of COPD and chronic respiratory failure, and is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. Weaning from the ventilator may be challenging, and the patient may be at risk for respiratory failure.
* Adrenal crisis: The patient has adrenal insufficiency, which may lead to adrenal crisis if not properly managed.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease, which may worsen if not properly managed.
* Infection: The patient has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, and may be at risk for infection.
* Pressure ulcers: The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers, which may worsen if not properly managed.
* Cardiac complications: The patient has tachycardia and elevated troponins, which may indicate cardiac complications.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of diarrhea and may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications.

Based on this information, I recommend close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status, adrenal function, anemia, and infection risk. Additionally, the patient's wounds and pressure ulcers should be closely monitored and managed to prevent worsening.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic anemia, and chronic pleural effusion. He has been admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and is currently on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 97 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 102/53 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 98% on a tracheostomy tube with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 30%.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, with a platelet count of 392 K/uL. His troponin level is persistently elevated at 0.61, indicating possible demand ischemia. His liver function tests are normal, with a creatinine level of 0.7 mg/dL.

The patient's medication list includes furosemide (Lasix) for fluid management, heparin sodium for prophylaxis, and metoprolol for tachycardia management. He is also receiving tube feeds via a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube.

The patient's physical examination is significant for peripheral edema, anasarca, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with bronchiectasis. He has a stage III decubitus ulcer on his sacrum/coccyx and a stage IV ulcer on his left ear helix.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD and bronchiectasis make him susceptible to respiratory failure, which can be exacerbated by his current mechanical ventilation.
2. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's corticotropin test result is positive for adrenal insufficiency, which can lead to hypotension, tachycardia, and electrolyte imbalances.
3. Anemia: The patient's chronic anemia can lead to fatigue, weakness, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
4. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's anasarca and chronic pleural effusion can lead to electrolyte and fluid imbalances, which can be exacerbated by his current fluid management.
5. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia can lead to demand ischemia, which can be exacerbated by his current medication regimen.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis can lead to infection, which can be exacerbated by his current immunosuppressed state.
7. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia can lead to allergic reactions and anaphylaxis, which can be exacerbated by his current medication regimen.
8. Decubitus ulcers: The patient's decubitus ulcers can lead to infection, sepsis, and prolonged hospitalization.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic anemia, and chronic pleural effusion. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure, acute adrenal insufficiency, and peripheral edema.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 101 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 103/59 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 98% on a tracheostomy tube with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and pressure support ventilation (PSV).

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated troponin level, indicating possible myocardial infarction. His white blood cell count is stable, and his differential count shows a normal neutrophil count. His liver function tests are mildly elevated, and his kidney function is normal.

The patient's physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds at the bases, and his abdomen is soft and non-tender. He has a trace of edema in his upper extremities and no edema in his lower extremities.

The patient's medical history includes a long hospital course at another institution, with multiple complications, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and failure to wean from the ventilator. He has also had a tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement.

The patient's current plan includes continuing to wean him from the ventilator, increasing his diuretic medication, and monitoring his fluid status. He will also receive a stress dose of hydrocortisone to treat his adrenal insufficiency.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory disease and recent respiratory failure make him at risk for continued respiratory distress.
2. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency can lead to hypotension, electrolyte imbalances, and other complications if not properly managed.
3. Peripheral edema: The patient's peripheral edema can worsen if not managed properly, leading to increased risk of complications such as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
4. Anemia: The patient's chronic anemia can worsen if not managed properly, leading to increased risk of complications such as cardiovascular disease and infections.
5. Myocardial infarction: The patient's elevated troponin level indicates possible myocardial infarction, which can lead to cardiac complications if not managed properly.
6. Wound infections: The patient's decubitus ulcers and pressure ulcers make him at risk for wound infections, which can lead to sepsis and other complications.
7. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's adrenal insufficiency and chronic kidney disease make him at risk for electrolyte imbalances, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's PEG tube and history of gastrointestinal bleeding make him at risk for gastrointestinal complications such as perforation and hemorrhage.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications and improve his outcomes.

   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.  Continues
   to fail trache mask trials.
    #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean
   from ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.
   Patient did not tolerate trache mask trial for past two days. CXR today
   current wet read states not changed from previously.
   -Will continue to wean from vent, currently on PSV 5/5 with 30% FiO2.
   -Brochcoscopy
   - EMG?
   #. Anasarca: Improved.  An ultrasound was negative for an obstructive
   clot.  BUN and Cr stable, seem to be tolerating aggressive diuresis
   --Goal today is even/mildly negative
   --Lasix 40mg IV bid
    #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs, currently still pending
   - Continues on Prednisone 5mg PO daily per endocrine
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased
   ferritin.Retic index 1.17 indicating hypoproliferation.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   # Tachycardic: Elevated troponins, no CP; cardiology saw him on
   arrival, felt he did not require emergent cardiac catheterization,
   recommend medical management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of
   tachycardia and hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to
   0.61.  Metoprolol was increased out of concern for likely demand
   ischemia.  Could have poor renal function without elevated creatinine
   in the setting of very little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 25mg PO q6
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile. WBC count trending down.  Has had yeast
   and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely colonizers.
   Patient also has significant history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central
   line from OSH now pulled, no growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated, though trending down (today 7.1%). [**Month (only) 51**]
   be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   - Check CBC with diff tomorrow
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   #. EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be
   primary contact person, lives with mother and aware of wishes.
   #. DISPOSITION: ICU until can tolerate trache mask better

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchiectasis, and a recent hospital course at OSH with multiple complications. He is currently admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure, acute adrenal insufficiency, and other underlying conditions.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.3°C (99.1°F)
* Heart rate: 101 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 103/59 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 16 inspirations per minute (insp/min)
* Oxygen saturation: 98%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 9.9 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 28.4%
* Platelet count: 398 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 33 mg/dL
* Glucose: 98 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: normal
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.9 g/dL
* Calcium: 9.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.8 mg/dL

The patient's radiology results show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR) with no acute changes
* Computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest with findings suggestive of infection, but no tracheobronchomalacia

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Respiratory failure
* Acute adrenal insufficiency
* Anasarca (peripheral edema)
* Pleural effusion
* Chronic anemia
* Rash
* Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
* Myocardial infarction
* Impaired skin integrity
* Airway, inability to protect (risk for aspiration, altered gag, airway clearance, cough)

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Weaning from ventilator support
* Bronchoscopy
* Electrolyte and fluid management
* Adrenal insufficiency treatment with cortisone and prednisone
* Anemia management with iron studies and active transfusion service
* Tachycardic management with metoprolol
* Leukocytosis management with close monitoring and antibiotic stewardship
* Eosinophilia management with minimization of unnecessary medications and prednisone
* Wound care for decubitus ulcers
* Tube feeds via PEG tube
* Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer
* Full code status

The patient's disposition is to remain in the ICU until he can tolerate a tracheal mask better.

 EDEMA, PERIPHERAL
 PLEURAL EFFUSION, CHRONIC
 ANEMIA, CHRONIC
 RASH
 CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS, EMPHYSEMA)

 SEIZURE, WITHOUT STATUS EPILEPTICUS
 HYPERNATREMIA (HIGH SODIUM)
 ELECTROLYTE & FLUID DISORDER, OTHER
 .H/O RESPIRATORY FAILURE, CHRONIC

 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)

   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.  Continues
   to fail trache mask trials.
    #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean
   from ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.
   Patient did not tolerate trache mask trial for past two days. CXR today
   current wet read states not changed from previously.
   -Will continue to wean from vent, currently on PSV 5/5 with 30% FiO2.
   -Brochcoscopy
   - EMG?
    #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs, currently still pending
   - Continues on Prednisone 5mg PO daily per endocrine
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Anasarca: Improved.  An ultrasound was negative for an obstructive
   clot.  BUN and Cr stable, seem to be tolerating aggressive diuresis
   --Goal today is even/mildly negative
   --Lasix 40mg IV bid
   #. Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased
   ferritin.Retic index 1.17 indicating hypoproliferation.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   # Tachycardic: Elevated troponins, no CP; cardiology saw him on
   arrival, felt he did not require emergent cardiac catheterization,
   recommend medical management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of
   tachycardia and hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to
   0.61.  Metoprolol was increased out of concern for likely demand
   ischemia.  Could have poor renal function without elevated creatinine
   in the setting of very little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 25mg PO q6
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile. WBC count trending down.  Has had yeast
   and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely colonizers.
   Patient also has significant history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central
   line from OSH now pulled, no growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated, though trending down (today 7.1%). [**Month (only) 51**]
   be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   #. EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchiectasis, and tracheobronchomalacia. He was recently admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure and has been unable to tolerate tracheostomy mask trials.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 11 cmH2O and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 30%. His respiratory rate (RR) is 16 breaths per minute, and his arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.33, pCO2 of 33 mmHg, and pO2 of 102 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has tachycardia with a heart rate of 101 beats per minute, and his troponin levels are elevated at 0.61. He is being managed with metoprolol 25mg PO q6h.
* Hematologic: The patient has anemia, likely due to chronic disease, with a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL. He is being monitored with daily complete blood counts (CBCs) and is receiving iron supplementation.
* Infectious disease: The patient has a history of yeast and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. He is not receiving antibiotics at this time.
* Endocrine: The patient has adrenal insufficiency, confirmed by cortisotropin syn test, and is being treated with prednisone 5mg PO daily. He is scheduled for an outpatient appointment with an endocrinologist.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a history of diarrhea, and his stool cultures have been negative for Clostridioides difficile (C. diff). He is receiving tube feeds via a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further adjustments to his mechanical ventilation settings or consideration for tracheostomy.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency requires close monitoring, and he may require further adjustments to his medication regimen.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia may require further evaluation and treatment, including blood transfusions.
* Infectious disease: The patient's history of yeast and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures may indicate a risk for further infections, and he should be monitored closely for signs of sepsis.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient's history of diarrhea and C. diff-negative stool cultures may indicate a risk for further gastrointestinal complications, including Clostridioides difficile infection.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's tachycardia and elevated troponin levels may indicate a risk for further cardiac complications, including myocardial infarction.

The patient's disposition is planned for rehabilitation as soon as a bed is available.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic anemia, and chronic pleural effusion. He has been admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure and has undergone tracheostomy placement.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is currently on a tracheostomy tube and is tolerating it well. He is on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) with a peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 5 cmH2O and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 30%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has elevated troponins and is considered to have demand ischemia. He is receiving metoprolol 25mg PO q6 and ASA.
* Hematological status: The patient has anemia, likely due to chronic disease, and is receiving daily HCT and minimizing unnecessary lab draws.
* Infectious status: The patient has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, which are likely colonizers. He has also had a central line infection, which has been treated with antibiotics.
* Skin status: The patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on his sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on his left ear helix. He is receiving wound care and frequent repositioning.
* Endocrine status: The patient has adrenal insufficiency and is receiving cortisone replacement therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk for further deterioration. He may require increased ventilatory support or consideration for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
* Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins and demand ischemia put him at risk for cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
* Infections: The patient's history of central line infections and colonization with yeast and pseudomonas bacteria put him at risk for further infections, including sepsis and pneumonia.
* Skin breakdown: The patient's skin ulcers are at risk for further deterioration and may require surgical debridement or skin grafting.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency may require further management, including stress doses of cortisone, to prevent adrenal crisis.

Based on this information, it is recommended that the patient continue to receive close monitoring and management in the ICU to prevent and treat potential complications.

   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.  Continues
   to fail trache mask trials.
    #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean
   from ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.
   Patient did not tolerate trache mask trial for past two days. However,
   today patient appears to be doing well on trache mask trial up in
   chair. CXR today current wet read states not changed from previously.
   Make sure that up in chair when trache masking.
   -Will continue to wean from vent, currently on PSV 5/5 with 30% FiO2.
   -PT consult to work with patient for strength, out of bed.
   #. Anasarca: Improved.  An ultrasound was negative for an obstructive
   clot.  BUN and Cr stable, seem to be tolerating aggressive diuresis
   --Goal today is even/mildly negative  (-250 mL)
   --Lasix 40mg IV bid
    #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs, currently still pending
   - Continues on Prednisone 5mg PO daily per endocrine
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased
   ferritin.Retic index 1.17 indicating hypoproliferation.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   # Tachycardic: Elevated troponins, no CP; cardiology saw him on
   arrival, felt he did not require emergent cardiac catheterization,
   recommend medical management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of
   tachycardia and hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to
   0.61.  Metoprolol was increased out of concern for likely demand
   ischemia.  Could have poor renal function without elevated creatinine
   in the setting of very little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 25mg PO q6
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile. WBC count stable.  Has had yeast and
   pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient
   also has significant history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line
   from OSH now pulled, no growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated, though trending down (today 7.1%). [**Month (only) 51**]
   be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   - Check CBC with diff tomorrow
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   -Check albumin
   -Make sure that tube feeds optimized.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.

   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be

Summary:

The patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), tracheobronchomalacia, and chronic anemia. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure and acute adrenal insufficiency. He has been on mechanical ventilation and tracheostomy tube for several days.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 101 bpm, and blood pressure of 103/59 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 98% on 30% FiO2.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponins, indicating possible demand ischemia. His white blood cell count is stable, but his eosinophil count is elevated, possibly due to adrenal insufficiency or medications.

The patient has several medical complications, including anasarca, chronic pleural effusion, chronic bronchiectasis, and stage III and IV decubitus ulcers. He is also experiencing hypernatremia and electrolyte imbalance.

The patient's plan of care includes continued weaning from mechanical ventilation, diuresis, and management of his adrenal insufficiency. He will also require outpatient appointments with endocrinology and pulmonology.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD and tracheobronchomalacia make him prone to respiratory failure. Weaning from mechanical ventilation may be challenging.
2. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency requires close monitoring and management. Cortisol replacement therapy may be necessary.
3. Anasarca: The patient's fluid overload and electrolyte imbalance may worsen his anasarca. Aggressive diuresis and electrolyte management are necessary.
4. Chronic bronchiectasis: The patient's chronic bronchiectasis may lead to recurrent respiratory infections and exacerbations of his COPD.
5. Decubitus ulcers: The patient's stage III and IV decubitus ulcers require close monitoring and management to prevent further progression and infection.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia requires close monitoring and management to prevent further worsening and potential complications.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance requires close monitoring and management to prevent further worsening and potential complications.
8. Infection: The patient's history of VAP and colonization with yeast and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures makes him prone to infection. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current status as follows:

The patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchiectasis, and tracheobronchomalacia. He has been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure and has undergone tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement. The patient has failed trache mask trials in the past, but today appears to be doing well with the trache mask trial up in a chair.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.3°C (99.1°F)
* Heart rate: 101 bpm (90-104 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 103/59 mmHg (69-112/64 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 16 inspirations per minute (15-29 inspirations per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous pressure (CVP) and pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) are not mentioned.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 9.9-11.0 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 25.2-28.4%
* Platelet count: 392-398 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.5-0.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 33-40 mg/dL
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient has hypernatremia (high sodium) and is receiving diuretic therapy with furosemide.

The patient's radiology results show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): Preliminary read shows no change.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Adrenal insufficiency (AI)
* Edema, peripheral
* Pleural effusion, chronic
* Anemia, chronic
* Rash
* Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) without acute exacerbation
* Seizure, without status epilepticus
* Hypernatremia (high sodium)
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder, other

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue weaning from the ventilator
* PT consult to work with the patient for strength and out-of-bed activities
* Continue diuretic therapy with furosemide
* Cortisotropin syn test for adrenal insufficiency
* Daily HCT and minimize unnecessary lab draws
* Active T&S
* Continue ASA and Metoprolol for cardiac management
* Monitor fever curve
* Minimize unnecessary medications
* Check CBC with diff tomorrow
* Continue wound care and repositioning
* Optimize tube feeds
* Continue DVT prophylaxis with heparin SQ and pneumoboots
* Continue ulcer prophylaxis with ranitidine

The patient's disposition is ICU until he can tolerate trache mask better.

   -Will continue to wean from vent, currently on PSV 5/5 with 30% FiO2.
   -PT consult to work with patient for strength, out of bed.
   #Hypotension: Has been having episodes of hypotension. [**Month (only) 51**] have been
   over-diuresed.
   - 500 ml NS bolus
   - If not responding to bolus will increase Prednisone 10 mg PO daily as
   it may be secondary to adrenal insufficiency
    #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs, currently still pending
   - Continues on Prednisone 5mg PO daily per endocrine
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased
   ferritin.Retic index 1.17 indicating hypoproliferation.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   # Tachycardic: Elevated troponins, no CP; cardiology saw him on
   arrival, felt he did not require emergent cardiac catheterization,
   recommend medical management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of
   tachycardia and hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to
   0.61.  Metoprolol was increased out of concern for likely demand
   ischemia.  Could have poor renal function without elevated creatinine
   in the setting of very little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA

   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile. WBC count stable.  Has had yeast and
   pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient
   also has significant history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line
   from OSH now pulled, no growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   - Check CBC with diff tomorrow
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   -Check albumin

* Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient's rash may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as vision loss and eye damage.
* Ulcers: The patient's ulcers may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as infection and sepsis.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and ensure his optimal care.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchiectasis, and tracheobronchomalacia. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure and has been on mechanical ventilation for an extended period.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is on tracheal mask ventilation, and his respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 99%, and his arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows a pH of 7.33, pCO2 of 33 mmHg, and pO2 of 50 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: His heart rate is 114 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 104/55 mmHg. He has an elevated troponin level, indicating possible demand ischemia.
* Hematological: His white blood cell count is 9.9 x 10^9/L, and his platelet count is 473 x 10^9/L. He has anemia, likely due to chronic disease, and his reticulocyte index is 1.17, indicating hypoproliferation.
* Renal: His serum creatinine level is 0.7 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 32 mg/dL.
* Gastrointestinal: He has a stage III decubitus ulcer on his sacrum/coccyx and a stage IV ulcer on his left ear helix. He also has a circular healed pressure ulcer on his right postacromial process.
* Infectious: He has a history of diarrhea, and his urine and sputum cultures have grown yeast and pseudomonas, likely colonizers.

The patient's medications include:

* Lasix 40mg IV bid for edema
* Prednisone 5mg PO daily for adrenal insufficiency
* Metoprolol 25mg PO q6 for tachycardia
* Heparin SQ and pneumoboots for DVT prophylaxis
* Ranitidine for ulcer prophylaxis
* Nutren 2.0 (Full) via PEG tube for nutrition

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning from mechanical ventilation
* Physical therapy to improve strength and mobility
* Wound care for his decubitus ulcers
* Monitoring of his electrolyte and fluid status
* Follow-up with endocrinology and pulmonology for further management of his adrenal insufficiency and COPD

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to inadequate ventilation or infection
* Cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or myocardial infarction, due to tachycardia and hypotension
* Wound complications, such as infection or progression of his decubitus ulcers
* Electrolyte and fluid disorders due to his medications and underlying conditions
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as diarrhea or constipation, due to his medications and underlying conditions.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his multiple medical conditions to prevent potential complications and improve his outcome.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications and potential complications are identified:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and has failed trache mask trials. He is currently on non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) with 30% FiO2 and PSV 5/5.
2. Adrenal Insufficiency: The patient has been diagnosed with adrenal insufficiency, and cortisotropin syn test is positive. He is currently receiving prednisone 5mg PO daily and will require outpatient follow-up with endocrinology.
3. Anemia: The patient has likely anemia of chronic disease given his long hospital course and iron studies consistent with decreased TIBC and increased ferritin.
4. Tachycardia: The patient has elevated troponins, no CP, and cardiology has recommended medical management. He may have demand ischemia in the setting of tachycardia and hypotension.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient has a stable WBC count, and his fever curve is being monitored. He has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely colonizers.
6. Eosinophilia: The patient has elevated eosinophils, thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency, but still requires further evaluation and monitoring.
7. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient has a rash that is likely blepharitis, and his pilocarpine drops have been changed to bacitracin and vigamox, which seems to be helping.
8. Ulcers: The patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on left ear helix, both of which require frequent repositioning and wound care.
9. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient has hypernatremia and requires close monitoring of his electrolytes and fluid status.
10. Seizure: The patient has had a seizure, and his risk for future seizures is unknown.
11. Airway management: The patient has a tracheostomy and requires ongoing airway management to ensure safe and effective ventilation.

Potential complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate further, requiring more invasive ventilation or even intubation.
2. Adrenal crisis: The patient's adrenal insufficiency may lead to an adrenal crisis if his cortisol levels are not adequately replaced.
3. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and prolonged hospital stay increase his risk for infection, particularly respiratory and urinary tract infections.
4. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, and he may be at risk for bleeding, particularly with invasive procedures or trauma.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and elevated troponins may indicate cardiac complications, such as demand ischemia or cardiomyopathy.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's seizure and elevated troponins may indicate neurological complications, such as stroke or encephalopathy.
7. Wound complications: The patient's ulcers may become infected or worsen, leading to further complications and increased risk of sepsis.
8. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance may lead to further complications, such as arrhythmias or muscle weakness.

 ELECTROLYTE & FLUID DISORDER, OTHER
 .H/O RESPIRATORY FAILURE, CHRONIC
 ALTERATION IN NUTRITION
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)

   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.  Continues
   to fail trache mask trials.
    #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean
   from ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.
   Patient did well on trache mask trial up in chair yesterday, removed
   trache yesterday evening and [**Doctor Last Name 7198**] this well without drop in
   oxygenation per nursing. Make sure that up in chair when trache
   masking.
   -Will continue to wean from vent, currently on PSV 5/5 with 30% FiO2.
   -PT consult to work with patient for strength, out of bed.
   #Hypotension: Has been having episodes of hypotension. [**Month (only) 51**] have been
   over-diuresed.
   - 500 ml NS bolus
   - If not responding to bolus will increase Prednisone 10 mg PO daily as
   it may be secondary to adrenal insufficiency
    #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs, currently still pending
   - Continues on Prednisone 5mg PO daily per endocrine
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased
   ferritin.Retic index 1.17 indicating hypoproliferation.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   # Tachycardic: Elevated troponins, no CP; cardiology saw him on
   arrival, felt he did not require emergent cardiac catheterization,
   recommend medical management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of
   tachycardia and hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to
   0.61.  Metoprolol was increased out of concern for likely demand
   ischemia.  Could have poor renal function without elevated creatinine
   in the setting of very little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 25mg PO q6
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile. WBC count stable.  Has had yeast and
   pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient
   also has significant history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line
   from OSH now pulled, no growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   - Check CBC with diff tomorrow
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   -Check albumin
   -Make sure that tube feeds optimized.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   #. EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be
   primary contact person, lives with mother and aware of wishes.
   #. DISPOSITION: Rehab ASAP. As patient currently tolerating not being
   on trache mask even right now may consider calling out to the floor
   later if continues to look good on RA.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren 2.0 (Full) - [**2101-11-22**] 08:48 PM 40 mL/hour

Summary:

The patient, a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure, adrenal insufficiency, and other comorbidities. He was recently transferred from another hospital for further evaluation and management. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchiectasis, and tracheobronchomalacia, which has led to repeated hospitalizations and complications.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Respiratory failure, with a recent episode of hypoxia while off the ventilator
* Adrenal insufficiency, with a positive corticotropin stimulation test
* Anemia, likely due to chronic disease
* Tachycardia, with elevated troponins and a possible diagnosis of demand ischemia
* Leukocytosis, with stable WBC count and no evidence of infection
* Eosinophilia, possibly due to adrenal insufficiency or medications
* Right eye injection and macular orbital rash, likely due to blepharitis
* Decubitus ulcers on the sacrum and ear helix, with minimal drainage

The patient's current medications include:

* Furosemide (Lasix) for fluid management
* Prednisone for adrenal insufficiency
* Metoprolol for tachycardia and possible demand ischemia
* Tube feeds via PEG tube
* Heparin for DVT prophylaxis

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: continued weaning from the ventilator, with a risk of reintubation if the patient's respiratory status deteriorates
* Adrenal insufficiency: ongoing management with prednisone and close monitoring of cortisol levels
* Anemia: ongoing management with iron studies and transfusions as needed
* Tachycardia: ongoing management with metoprolol and close monitoring of troponin levels
* Leukocytosis: ongoing monitoring for signs of infection and close observation of the patient's WBC count
* Eosinophilia: ongoing monitoring for signs of allergic reactions or other complications
* Right eye injection and macular orbital rash: ongoing management with topical antibiotics and close monitoring of the patient's eye health
* Decubitus ulcers: ongoing management with wound care and frequent repositioning to prevent further breakdown.

   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.  Continues
   to fail trache mask trials.
    #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean
   from ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.
   Patient did well on trache mask trial up in chair yesterday, removed
   trache yesterday evening and [**Doctor Last Name 7198**] this well without drop in
   oxygenation per nursing. Make sure that up in chair when trache
   masking.
   -Will continue to wean from vent, currently on PSV 5/5 with 30% FiO2.
   -PT consult to work with patient for strength, out of bed.
   #Hypotension: Has been having episodes of hypotension.
   - 500 ml NS bolus
   - If not
    #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs, currently still pending
   - Continues on Prednisone 5mg PO daily per endocrine
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased
   ferritin.Retic index 1.17 indicating hypoproliferation.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   # Tachycardic: Elevated troponins, no CP; cardiology saw him on
   arrival, felt he did not require emergent cardiac catheterization,
   recommend medical management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of
   tachycardia and hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to
   0.61.  Metoprolol was increased out of concern for likely demand
   ischemia.  Could have poor renal function without elevated creatinine
   in the setting of very little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 25mg PO q6
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile. WBC count stable.  Has had yeast and
   pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient
   also has significant history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line
   from OSH now pulled, no growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   - Check CBC with diff tomorrow
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   -Check albumin
   -Make sure that tube feeds optimized.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.

   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   #. EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be
   primary contact person, lives with mother and aware of wishes.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic pleural effusion, chronic anemia, and chronic respiratory failure. He is currently in the ICU due to acute respiratory failure, adrenal insufficiency, and electrolyte and fluid disorders.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37°C (98.6°F)
* Heart rate: 114 bpm
* Blood pressure: 104/55 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 99%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 9.9 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 28.4%
* Platelets: 473 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Glucose: 98 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.61 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.1 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.1 g/dL
* Calcium: 9.4 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 5.3 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions and complications include:

* Respiratory failure due to COPD and tracheomalacia
* Adrenal insufficiency
* Electrolyte and fluid disorders
* Hypotension
* Anemia
* Leukocytosis
* Eosinophilia
* Right eye injection and macular orbital rash
* Decubitus ulcers on sacrum and ear helix
* Stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with minimal serous drainage
* Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix with very scant serous drainage
* Circular healed pressure ulcer on right post-acromium process

The patient's medications include:

* Furosemide (Lasix) 40mg every 12 hours
* Heparin sodium (Prophylaxis) 5000 units subcutaneously every 12 hours
* Prednisone 5mg daily
* Metoprolol 25mg every 6 hours
* ASA 81mg daily

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Weaning from ventilator support
* Physical therapy to improve strength and mobility
* Wound care for decubitus ulcers
* Optimization of tube feeds
* Monitoring for electrolyte and fluid disorders
* Follow-up with endocrine and pulmonology specialists

The patient's code status is full code, and his emergency contact is his daughter, who is aware of his wishes.

 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
 IMPAIRED SKIN INTEGRITY
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.  Continues
   to fail trache mask trials.
    #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean
   from ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.
   Patient did well on trache mask trial up in chair yesterday, removed
   trache yesterday evening and [**Doctor Last Name 7198**] this well without drop in
   oxygenation per nursing. Make sure that up in chair when trache
   masking.
   -Will continue to wean from vent, currently on PSV 5/5 with 30% FiO2.
   -PT consult to work with patient for strength, out of bed.
   #Hypotension: Has been having episodes of hypotension. [**Month (only) 51**] have been
   over-diuresed.
   - 500 ml NS bolus
   - If not responding to bolus will increase Prednisone 10 mg PO daily as
   it may be secondary to adrenal insufficiency
    #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs, currently still pending
   - Continues on Prednisone 5mg PO daily per endocrine
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased
   ferritin.Retic index 1.17 indicating hypoproliferation.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   # Tachycardic: Elevated troponins, no CP; cardiology saw him on
   arrival, felt he did not require emergent cardiac catheterization,
   recommend medical management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of
   tachycardia and hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to
   0.61.  Metoprolol was increased out of concern for likely demand
   ischemia.  Could have poor renal function without elevated creatinine
   in the setting of very little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 25mg PO q6
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile. WBC count stable.  Has had yeast and
   pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient
   also has significant history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line
   from OSH now pulled, no growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   - Check CBC with diff tomorrow
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   -Check albumin
   -Make sure that tube feeds optimized.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   #. EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be
   primary contact person, lives with mother and aware of wishes.
   #. DISPOSITION: Rehab!
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren 2.0 (Full) - [**2101-11-22**] 08:48 PM 40 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2101-11-13**] 09:45 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
